name: Mecipt
description:
The beginning of IT in Romania.

Professor V. Baltac said in the Conference "Computers and Computer Networks in Romania between 1953-2001", from The Romanian Academy, at 22 nov. 2001 that the years 1950 had marqued a Romanian priority in Romanian computing techniques.
Three computing techniques schools were then created:
- Bucharest - IFA (Institutul de Fizica Atomica - The Athomical Physics Institute),
- Timisoara - MECIPT (Masina Electronica de Calculat a Institutului Politehnic Timisoara - Electronical Computing Machine of the Polytechnical Institute of Timisoara),
- Cluj - DACICC (Dispozitiv Automat de Calcul al Institutului de Calcul din Cluj - Automated Computing Dispositive of the Computing Institute of Cluj).

MECIPT was a typical first generation computer.
It contained:
- Over 2000 electronic tubes,
- Tens of thousands passive components,
- Words of 30 bits,
- As external memory - drum equivalent of 3 kb,
- Data was input into computer by punched paper tape,
- As a printer was an electrical typing machine.
Its speed was about 50 operations/second and it was programmed in machine code.

MECIPT was one of the first romanian computers... It worked for the first time... I guess around 1961-1962.

Thanks to Stefan Deli for all this information.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MECIPT 3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Last version of the Mecipt series.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Stefan Deli</b></p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert introduced three new Digital professional computers: the <b>Professional 300 Series</b>, the <b>DECmate II</b>, and the <b>Rainbow 100</b> <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">All that personal computers needed were a few professional standards. <br><br> Until now, manufacturer have made personal computers that were a hopeful compromise between home and use business. But now, Digital Equipment Corporation offers the first personal computers designed and built strictly for professional use. And since different professionals have different needs, Digital is introducing not one, but three personal computers made to professional standards.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID SITUATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>A translation would be : "the 10 years old and more children appreciate quickly the computing principles and have a lot of fun with their ZX-80" <br><br> So they say...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 3 PAGE U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>First HX-20 U.S. advert (september 1982)<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The size, of course, is a dead giveaway. But don't let the size fool you. The HX-20 is not a toy. Or a glorified calculator.<br> It's a computer.<br> A real computer with 16K RAM<br>...<br> Surprised that a computer like the HX-20 should come from Epson?<br> You shouldn't be. Because we have been building computers in Japan since 1978. And we have been practicing ultra-high-quality precision manufacturing for a lot longer than that.<br><br> We didn't jump right into the American microcomputer market. We could afford to bide our time; to wait for the product that was going to stand America on its ears.<br> This is it.<br> The Epson HX-20</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl !  Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OFFICIAL FLYER (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mainbyte.com" target="_blank">www.mainbyte.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DMS-15</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983 advert.<br><br> The DMS-15 is a DMS-3/F with a built-in 15 MB hard disk.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a part of a complete French price list of the C64 and VIC-20, including peripherals, accessories and software.<br> You can download the <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Commodore/FrPriceList.zip">complete version</a>.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEO-GEO ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://spoonman.roarvgm.com/neogeo/" target="_blank">SpoonMan's Neo-Geo page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> I LEARN AT SCHOOL</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for the new model, dated april 1986. <br><br> "I learn at school, I rock at home"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>
